subject: RE: [junit] Re: Testing Private Methods

messageBody:
> -----Original Message-----
> From: Steven Taschuk [mailto:staschuk@...]
> Sent: Friday, December 20, 2002 12:15 AM
> To: junit@yahoogroups.com
> Subject: Re: [junit] Re: Testing Private Methods
>
>
> Quoth Michael Silverstein:
> [...]
> > There's no need to use private methods to test this.
> Assuming the code
> > paths for the two constructors converge at some point immediately
> > after the input String is parsed, you can test the parsing code and
> > the date processing code separately.
>
> Indeed. But if I take the view that tests should test
> behaviour rather than code, then I have to consider 'partwise
> constructor fails for (2002,2,29)' and 'parsing constructor
> fails for "2002-02-29"' to be separate behaviours, both
> deserving to be tested. That they almost certainly use the
> same code is an implementation detail with which the tests
> ought not to be concerned, and ought not to assume.

Yes and no. It's your job as developer to test everything that can fail,
but no more than that. To a large degree, your knowledge of the
implementation and risks involved help drive that. The paragraph above
is based on the assumption that you *know* that the code paths converge
early. If that were not the case you would have to proceed differently.

> For example, if at some point in the future these
> constructors are changed to use separate implementations of
> the constraint checks for some reason, I'd like the tests I
> write now to remain valid and complete. If I assume the
> parsing constructor uses the same code as the partwise
> constructor, such a change silently makes the tests incomplete.

For what its worth, this runs counter to XP. You are proposing doing
extra work now in anticipation of a possible change in requirements or
implementation in the future. I'll leave suggesting whether this is a
bad thing or not to those who like to debate these things. On the one
hand there are valid reasons for not doing work in anticipation of
requirements or changes that may never happen. On the other hand, if you
later make a change that invalidates the overriding assumption that the
code paths converge, and don't correspondingly update the tests, then
you have, as you said, incomplete tests. On the other hand, regular use
of a code coverage tool should uncover testing omissions for you
automatically.

Personally, I'd implement it the easy way and put comments in the code
to remind me to update the test if I ever went back and refactored the
constructor. On top of that, I'd make it a habit to regularly run the
tests under the aegis of a code coverage tool just as a sanity check for
the tests themselves.

> [...]
> > I'd also make a bunch of helper methods, such as one that takes a
> > partwise date specification and an expected exception, and then
> > instantiates using both constructors, asserting that both cause the
> > expected exception to be thrown. That way you're not
> replicating a lot
> > of code.
>
> Quite. Unless I've missed something, this is essentially the
> same solution as I proposed at the end of my last post.
>

Yup. I just didn't read down far enough in your post. What'd they say
about great minds again? :-)
